content: No, the Clerk of the House of Commons is a non-partisan and impartial official who provides advice and guidance to Members of Parliament on parliamentary procedure and constitutional matters. The Clerk does not have a role in drafting legislation or in influencing the content of Bills being debated in the House. Their role is to ensure that the procedures are followed correctly according to the rules, so that the Bills can be discussed and debated in the House properly. They do not take a position on the substance of the legislation.
